I don't remember it. :) I have a role as a cultural historian in the crypto community. Around since 1996 or so. I keep talking about ITAR and eGold, writing stuff like https:// medium.com/humanizing-the -singularity/2018-year-in-preview-the-future-of-cryptocurrency-b99110480ff0?993738 … slow progress towards understanding let me say. Very slow. People don't learn easily.

So my approach to crypto is unleavened with irrational enthusiasm. I look to the downsides, I look to regulation, I question assumptions. We could get a better world out of this. If we were better people. But as things are it's going to be touch and go!

I'm experienced. I saw the ITAR regulations push my people out of America. I saw the shutdown of eGold. I'm a veteran of the "just outside of the blast radius" periphery of crypto, and I've been there for more than 20 years. Crypto is munitions was the first thing I learned.
